children.subject: I cant tell my performance since I dont know the averages but I get around half right although I do get a lot of subtle errors such as off by one errors.

Something I do to really test my understanding is redo a hw or practice exam until I can get it completely correct on my own. Sometimes after reading a solution to a problem I get wrong I convince myself I understand and the solution becomes "obvious" but this is often not equivalent to being able to come up with the solution on my own and make 0 mistakes. This approach takes a lot of time but the classes I've done best in were usually the ones where I did this sort of method in exam prep.

I'll try that for next time! Thanks for the tip!

-OP
How do you perform on the practice exams?

I feel the same way OP. No matter what kinda studying style I try, it's usually always 0.5-1.5 deviations below. HWs/Projects are my only saving grace in most CS courses. 

I also did poorly on this midterm, due to several off-by-one errors and whatnot, and it feels pretty demotivating.
Maybe, but I do still get my part of the work done, and I understand it at the time. Sometimes I wonder it's because I have terrible memory or something.

might be an issue not with how much you're doing but how you're studying. sometimes you think youre grinding and putting in the hours and should be rewarded, but then it turns out those hours weren't actually spent doing 100% or having small distractions or something. maybe pay attention to this and if you aren't in the right groove change where/when/for how long/the nature of your studying

Just some thoughts, these are things you didn't mention that helped me in other classes:

Group study is really helpful. Sometimes I think I understand a concept well and feel really confident about it, and after disagreeing with a group member and having a discussion about who's right, I learn a lot more about the concept. The key point is that you and your group members have to argue. Maybe I realize some subtleties I didn't think about before, maybe I had a fundamental misunderstanding, or I have a chance to demonstrate that I really do get it as well as I thought I did. This helped a lot in a concept heavy class like 61B, and would probably help for something like 186 that's also pretty concept-heavy. 

Also OH can still be really helpful for conceptual help, it sounds like you're going during homework deadlines. 186 has so many office hours, the ones in the morning and late evening earlier in the week are sometimes sparsely attended. I've been to a few where it's literally just me and two other people. So I wouldn't give up entirely on OH if I were you.

history.content:
Hi all, 

I'm making this post for some course studying advice.

So I just got my midterm score back for CS 186, and although I thought I did well, I actually ended up doing almost an STD below average.

This is the 8th CS exam in a row where I did around 1 STD below average if not more for some exams.

I'm trying to see what I'm doing wrong, and I just find it frustrating that I can't find my issue in my studying style to be frank.

To give context, I like to review the lectures, take practice exams, and go to all the discussions.

I make sure I can understand the material by iterating it to other people and seeing if they understand what I am saying.

After practicing on concepts, I always make sure I can do a similar styled problem so that I can reinforce my understanding of the material.

I try to go to office hours, but in general, the queue tends to be an hour long and so that doesn't really help at all. 

I try to do every guerilla section, and try to allocate time to review my hw's and projects.

Overall, it just feels like I just flat out choke when it comes to taking exams, and it has seriously been pissing me off that I am consistently underperforming. Also, it sometimes feels like I get no credit for a LOT of problems for an off by one error and that does drop my scores too I guess.

Any advice?

Feel free to roast me haha
history.subject: Help with CS courses
